summary: This is a legal memorandum filed by Ghislaine Maxwell's defense team in support of a motion to dismiss the superseding indictment. The defense argues the indictment was obtained in violation of the Sixth Amendment because the grand jury was drawn from the White Plains Division, which allegedly systematically underrepresented Black and Hispanic residents compared to the Manhattan Division where the alleged crimes occurred. The filing references procedural history and expert analysis on jury composition.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: The defendant in the criminal case, accused of involvement in Jeffrey Epstein's crimes. Her defense team is filing this motion to dismiss the indictment.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Referenced as the individual whose New York residence is the alleged location of unlawful sexual activity involving Minor Victim-1. The indictment of Maxwell is noted to have occurred around the anniversary of Epstein's indictment.

persons.name: Mark S. Cohen
persons.context: Attorney for Ghislaine Maxwell from Cohen & Gresser LLP, who signed the memorandum.

persons.name: Christian R. Everdell
persons.context: Attorney for Ghislaine Maxwell from Cohen & Gresser LLP, who signed the certificate of service.

persons.name: Jeffrey S. Pagliuca

persons.name: Laura A. Menninger

persons.name: Bobbi C. Stemheim
persons.context: Attorney for Ghislaine Maxwell from the Law Offices of Bobbi C. Stemheim.

persons.name: Jeffrey Martin
persons.context: An expert who analyzed the racial and ethnic composition of the master and qualified jury wheels for Manhattan and White Plains, cited in a declaration in the U.S. v. Balde case.

persons.name: Judge Faillzt
persons.context: Presiding judge in the U.S. v. Balde case in the Southern District of New York, referenced as the court where a similar challenge to the use of a White Plains grand jury was pending.

events.title: Indictment of Ghislaine Maxwell
events.description: The government filed a sealed indictment against Ghislaine Maxwell in the Manhattan Division of the Southern District of New York.

events.title: Announcement and Arrest of Ghislaine Maxwell
events.description: The government announced the indictment and arrest of Ghislaine Maxwell, which the defense alleges was timed to coincide with the anniversary of Jeffrey Epstein's indictment.

events.title: Manhattan Grand Jury Seated
events.description: According to an email from a court official cited in the document, a Manhattan grand jury was seated, four days before Maxwell's indictment.

events.title: Filing of Motion to Dismiss
events.description: Ghislaine Maxwell's defense team filed this memorandum in support of a motion to dismiss the superseding indictment.

keyFacts: The defense argues Ghislaine Maxwell's indictment was obtained in violation of the Sixth Amendment because the grand jury was drawn from the White Plains Division, which allegedly systematically underrepresented Black and Hispanic residents compared to the Manhattan Division.

An expert analysis by Jeffrey Martin found the White Plains qualified jury wheel was 8.76% Black and 10.48% Hispanic, compared to the Manhattan Division's eligible juror population of 20.92% Black and 28.06% Hispanic, indicating significant underrepresentation.

The defense claims the government used a White Plains grand jury to meet a 'publicity-driven' deadline of July 2, 2020, the anniversary of Jeffrey Epstein's indictment, even though a Manhattan grand jury was available by June 25, 2020.

The indictment references Epstein's Upper East Side residence in Manhattan as the specific location where Maxwell allegedly intended for a minor victim to engage in unlawful sexual activity with Epstein.
The motion is part of the case U.S. v. Balde, No. 1:20-cr-00281-KPF, where a similar challenge to the use of a White Plains grand jury for a Manhattan case was raised.
